title: Major Depression Inventory (MDI)
description: Screens for depression and provides both diagnosis and severity assessment using WHO-developed criteria

parameters.name: depressed_mood
parameters.description: How much of the time during the past 2 weeks have you felt sad or depressed?

parameters.name: lack_of_interest
parameters.description: How much of the time during the past 2 weeks have you lost interest in your daily activities?

parameters.name: lack_of_energy
parameters.description: How much of the time during the past 2 weeks have you felt lacking in energy and strength?

parameters.name: low_self_confidence
parameters.description: How much of the time during the past 2 weeks have you felt less self-confident?

parameters.name: bad_conscience
parameters.description: How much of the time during the past 2 weeks have you had a bad conscience or feelings of guilt?

parameters.name: life_not_worth_living
parameters.description: How much of the time during the past 2 weeks have you felt that life wasn't worth living?

parameters.name: concentration_problems
parameters.description: How much of the time during the past 2 weeks have you had difficulty concentrating?

parameters.name: agitation_restlessness
parameters.description: How much of the time during the past 2 weeks have you felt very restless?

parameters.name: psychomotor_retardation
parameters.description: How much of the time during the past 2 weeks have you felt that your movements have been slower?

parameters.name: sleep_problems
parameters.description: How much of the time during the past 2 weeks have you had trouble sleeping at night?

result.name: mdi_score
result.description: MDI total score and depression severity classification

ranges.interpretation: No evidence of clinically significant depression. Continue routine monitoring and preventive care. Consider lifestyle factors and general mental health promotion.

Mild depression present. Consider watchful waiting, psychosocial interventions, counseling, or brief therapy. Monitor closely for symptom progression. Lifestyle modifications and social support may be beneficial.
Moderate depression requiring treatment. Consider psychotherapy and/or antidepressant medication. Regular follow-up essential. Assess for functional impairment and safety concerns.
Severe depression requiring immediate treatment. Strong indication for combined therapy (psychotherapy + medication). Assess suicide risk. Consider psychiatric referral and intensive monitoring.

references: Bech P, Rasmussen NA, Olsen LR, Noerholm V, Abildgaard W. The sensitivity and specificity of the Major Depression Inventory, using the Present State Examination as the index of diagnostic validity. J Affect Disord. 2001 Oct;66(2-3):159-64.
Olsen LR, Jensen DV, Noerholm V, Martiny K, Bech P. The internal and external validity of the Major Depression Inventory in measuring severity of depressive states. Psychol Med. 2003 Feb;33(2):351-6.

Cuijpers P, Li J, Hofmann SG, Andersson G. Self-reported versus clinician-rated symptoms of depression as outcome measures in psychotherapy research on depression: a meta-analysis. Clin Psychol Rev. 2010 Nov;30(7):768-78.
formula: Sum of 10 items scored 0-3 each, with diagnostic algorithms for ICD-10 and DSM-IV criteria
notes: Developed by WHO and Professor Per Bech in Denmark
Available free of charge with full manual
Provides both diagnostic and severity assessment
Based on ICD-10 and DSM-IV criteria for major depression
Requires symptoms present for at least 2 weeks
Item 6 (life not worth living) requires careful suicide risk assessment
Should be combined with clinical interview for formal diagnosis
Useful for monitoring treatment response over time
Consider cultural and linguistic factors in interpretation
